Amsterdam & Region Travel Ticket | I amsterdam Skip to main content Discover Amsterdam Live, Work and Study Meetings and Conventions Business English Discover Amsterdam What's on See and do Travel and stay City Card and tickets Discover Amsterdam City Card & Tickets Amsterdam & Region Travel Ticket Image from Koen Dijkstra Amsterdam & Region Travel Ticket Updated 13 March 2025 at 15:40 A simple and convenient way to explore the Amsterdam Area is with the Amsterdam & Region Travel Ticket. This convenient multi-purpose ticket offers unlimited public transport by bus, tram, train and metro. You can purchase your ticket online or at the I amsterdam Store and selected transport ticket counters. Public transport pass for Amsterdam and the Amsterdam Area Image from koen smilde The Amsterdam & Region Travel Ticket allows you to explore all that Amsterdam has to offer, along with the iconic sights and scenery of the surrounding area. Tickets are available for one, two or three consecutive days, so that you can use it for a day trip, weekend break or three-day excursion. A map filled with sightseeing tips is included with your ticket to inspire you. Find out more about accessibility on public transport in Amsterdam Download the map and public transport guide (pdf) Get the Amsterdam Regional Travel Ticket online Where to buy the Amsterdam & Region Travel Ticket Image from Creative bros The card is available for purchase online or at the I amsterdam Store at Amsterdam Central Station, selected hotels and campsites and ticket counters of the participating public transport companies, including: GVB Tickets & Info: Amsterdam Central Station (Stationsplein), Bijlmer ArenA Station, Noord Station & Zuid Station EBS Tickets & Info: Amsterdam Central Station (IJ River side), Purmerend Tramplein, Edam bus station Connexxion Tickets & Info: Amsterdam Airport Schiphol (Schiphol Plaza) Ticket prices 1 day - €21,- 2 days - €31,50 3 days - €40,50 How to use the Amsterdam & Region Travel Ticket Image from Creative bros Tickets are valid for 1, 2 or 3 calendar days. A day in this context begins at 00:00 and ends the next day at 04:00. You must check in and out with your card whenever you enter and exit a bus, tram, train or metro. Your ticket is activated from the first check-in. Tickets are valid on all metro, tram and bus lines operated by GVB, Connexxion, AllGo and EBS, including night buses. While the flowers bloom between March and May, you can use the ticket to travel from Amsterdam Airport Schiphol to Keukenhof Gardens (Qbuzz bus 858). Tickets are also valid on NS trains in the Amsterdam Area. If you have questions or your ticket appears defective, visit any of the sales locations listed above for assistance. Wheelchair-accessible hotels in Amsterdam | I amsterdam Skip to main content Discover Amsterdam Live, Work and Study Meetings and Conventions Business English Discover Amsterdam What's on See and do Travel and stay City Card and tickets Discover Amsterdam Travel and stay Where to stay Wheelchair-accessible hotels in Amsterdam Wheelchair-accessible hotels in Amsterdam Updated 6 August 2025 at 07:22 Written by Josephine Rees Amsterdam offers a wide range of hotels across the city, many of which are wheelchair-accessible and equipped with thoughtful amenities for guests with mobility needs. From modern city-centre hotels to charming neighbourhood stays, these accessible accommodations ensure comfort and convenience for all. Discover the best wheelchair-friendly hotels in Amsterdam, perfectly located near popular sights, museums, and transport hubs. Hotel Jakarta Image from Josephine Rees Hotel Jakarta is a modern Amsterdam hotel known for its lush green interior and commitment to sustainability. Guests can enjoy various amenities, including wellness facilities, a restaurant and an on-site bakery. Hotel Jakarta has two wheelchair-friendly rooms, conveniently located near a lift. When booking online, please specify if you need a disabled parking space with your reservation. The accessible rooms include a double bed, a toilet equipped with grab rails, a shower with a built-in seat, a bathtub, and two balconies. Furniture such as desks and shelves are set at lower heights for convenience, and a full-length mirror is available. While all wellness facilities are step-free, not all are fully wheelchair-accessible. The hotel has one spacious disabled parking bay and is situated just 70 metres from the closest bus stop. Hotel Jakarta | Javakade 766, Oostelijk Havengebied The Social Hub Amsterdam City Image from Josephine Rees Just steps away from Wibaustraat metro station, The Social Hub (Amsterdam City location) is a vibrant space that welcomes students, professionals, and travellers alike. The hotel features several cafes, event venues, meeting rooms, and co-working spaces. The Social Hub Amsterdam City’s wheelchair-friendly room has a double bed and space to manoeuvre comfortably. The bathroom is equipped with grab rails on both sides of the toilet, a built-in shower chair, grab bars in the shower, a low sink, a low mirror, and an alarm cord. The hotel is conveniently located near the Wibautstraat metro station (which has one lift) and also offers private parking. When booking a wheelchair-accessible room online, select the ‘Deluxe King Room’ option and include a note in the comments requesting the wheelchair-accessible room. The Social Hub Amsterdam City | Wibautstraat 129, Oost Best Western Amsterdam Image from Josephine Rees Best Western Amsterdam is situated just west of the city centre, offering easy access to the city's main attractions via public transportation. The hotel features several wheelchair-friendly rooms, including a spacious family room accommodating up to three guests. Best Western Amsterdam offers four wheelchair-friendly rooms, with double and triple occupancy options. Each bathroom is equipped with a sturdy shower seat, grab rails beside the toilet, low sinks and mirrors, and an alarm cord. Some of the smaller accessible rooms may need furniture rearranged for better manoeuvrability. The hotel lobby and breakfast area are accessible. Breakfast is served as a self-service buffet, so wheelchair users may require assistance with carrying their trays. The hotel fitness centre currently isn’t wheelchair-accessible due to steps at the entrance. The hotel parking lot has several spaces, with several soon-to-be-designated disabled parking spaces in the near future. Best Western Amsterdam | Voorburgstraat 250, Nieuw-West Kimpton de Witt Image from Josephine Rees Kimpton De Witt is a stylish boutique hotel located a stone’s throw from Amsterdam Central Station. Its elegant, wheelchair-accessible rooms combine comfort with Dutch-inspired design. The hotel also includes Californian-style restaurant Celia , cocktail bar Super Lyan , Celia Café, a fitness centre, business facilities, and several conference rooms. The main hotel entrance is equipped with a platform lift and a ramp. The hotel features three wheelchair-friendly rooms on the first floor — one with a king-sized bed and two with twin beds. These rooms include a full-length mirror, low shelves, low hooks, and many (but not all) amenities placed within reach when seated. The large bathrooms include a built-in shower seat, grab rails on both sides of the toilet and an alarm cord. The business centre, fitness centre, and Beachwood Lounge are all step-free. Both Celia and Celia Cafe are wheelchair-accessible as well. Please note, however, that breakfast is served as a self-service buffet, which may require assistance for wheelchair users. Cocktail bar Super Lyan features high tables and can become quite busy, potentially making navigation challenging for wheelchair users. Guests are welcome to request a cocktail at one of the lower tables nearby. Kimpton de Witt | Nieuwezijds Voorburgwal 5, Centrum Crowne Plaza Amsterdam Zuid Image from Josephine Rees The music-themed Crowne Plaza Amsterdam Zuid hotel is a short stroll from Amsterdam Zuid Station. Guests can participate in social events like Sunday's Sip & Paint at De Japanner or enjoy live jazz on Thursdays at the Manhattan Lounge Bar. For a fun get-together in a private atmosphere with friends, there’s even a soundproof karaoke room! Crowne Plaza Amsterdam South offers several spacious wheelchair-friendly rooms with a double bed. Each room is equipped with a safe, coffee machine, mini fridge, and other amenities — though some items may need to be repositioned lower for easier access by wheelchair users. The bathroom includes a toilet with grab rails, a low sink and mirror, and an alarm cord. As the hotel does not currently provide its own shower seat, guests will need to arrange its rental externally if required. The hotel’s fitness centre, executive lounge, and various bars and restaurants are all threshold-free. Underground (paid) parking is available via the Q Park Symphony. Crowne Plaza Amsterdam Zuid | George Gershwinlaan 101, Zuid Mövenpick Hotel Amsterdam City Centre Image from Josephine Rees The Mövenpick Hotel Amsterdam City Centre offers generous space and comfort, with several wheelchair-friendly rooms. The hotel also includes accessible wellness facilities and a range of conference and event spaces. Mövenpick Hotel Amsterdam City Centre has several wheelchair-accessible rooms in a variety of sizes. These rooms feature a selection of coffee and tea amenities, wardrobes with adjustable-height hangers, and large bathrooms equipped with grab rails and a built-in shower seat. The fitness centre and sauna are both spacious and step-free, although they do not currently have specialised equipment for wheelchair users. The on-site restaurant is accessible. As breakfast is served as a self-service buffet, wheelchair users may require assistance carrying trays. The hotel further includes 11 wheelchair-accessible conference rooms of varying sizes. Underground parking is available, with several designated disabled parking spaces. Mövenpick Hotel Amsterdam City Centre | Piet Heinkade 11, Centrum Olympic Hotel Amsterdam Image from Josephine Rees Located in the southwest of Amsterdam, the Olympic Hotel is a contemporary and spacious hotel with four wheelchair-accessible ‘Paralympic Rooms’. The hotel has past experience meeting specific accessibility needs, such as arranging and setting up height-adjustable beds. The Olympic Hotel’s ‘Paralympic Rooms’ feature twin beds, generous space for wheelchair manoeuvring, and floor-to-ceiling windows with expansive views. However, the temperature control panel, some hooks, and the wardrobe rail are currently positioned too high for wheelchair users. The accessible bathroom includes a toilet with grab rails, and a shower seat is available upon request. The hotel restaurant has tables at varying heights, and breakfast is served buffet-style. Conference rooms are wheelchair-accessible, and the fitness centre is step-free. Unfortunately, the sauna and hot tub are not currently wheelchair-friendly due to their steps and narrow entrances. The hotel has underground parking accessible via a lift, as well as an outdoor parking lot. Olympic Hotel Amsterdam | IJsbaanpad 12, Zuid Corendon Amsterdam New-West, a Tribute Portfolio Hotel Image from J Filipe Wiens Part of the Tribute Portfolio hotel group, Corendon Amsterdam New-West has four wheelchair-accessible rooms equipped with various facilities for a comfortable stay. Guests can enjoy wellness facilities and dine at Mondi , the hotel’s Caribbean-inspired restaurant. Corendon Amsterdam New-West is a modern property offering four wheelchair-friendly rooms. Room doors are automated, and curtains can be operated electronically at the push of a button. In each wheelchair-friendly room, one of the twin beds can have the head and foot of the bed adjusted at an incline. The rooms feature low desks, low hooks, and various amenities (though some may need to be repositioned for better reach of wheelchair users). The bathroom includes grab rails on one side of the toilet, and a shower seat is available upon request. Please note that the spa and wellness facilities are limited in accessibility. The hotel has two disabled parking spaces in front of the main entrance. Corendon Amsterdam New-West | Aletta Jacobslaan 7, Nieuw-West Park Inn by Radisson Amsterdam City West Image from Josephine Rees Park Inn by Radisson Amsterdam City West is a modern hotel near Sloterdijk Station. It features three spacious wheelchair-accessible rooms. The hotel is also home to the Amsterdam Congress Centre , with varying-sized conference rooms for meetings and events. This hotel offers some of the most spacious accessible rooms to date, available in both double and triple formats. Rooms are equipped with various amenities, including low shelves and hooks. The temperature control panel, however, is positioned relatively high and difficult to reach when seated. The hotel restaurant (where breakfast, lunch and dinner are served) includes many tables located on a raised platform. Wheelchair users are encouraged to ask staff for assistance in arranging a suitable accessible table. The fitness centre is step-free. As part of the Amsterdam Congress Center , the hotel also has various wheelchair-accessible conference rooms in different sizes. Underground parking is available with several disabled parking spaces. Park Inn by Radisson Amsterdam City West | La Guardiaweg 59, Sloterdijk DoubleTree by Hilton Amsterdam Centraal Station Image from Josephine Rees DoubleTree by Hilton Amsterdam Centraal Station is an inviting, recently renovated hotel located in the heart of the city. It offers several wheelchair-friendly rooms, a variety of restaurants and cafés, fitness facilities, and meeting spaces. Guests can enjoy LuminAir, the hotel’s impressive accessible rooftop bar and terrace. DoubleTree by Hilton Amsterdam Centraal Station has fourteen wheelchair-friendly rooms (including a suite), four of which offer connecting doors to another hotel room. Eleven wheelchair-friendly rooms have a double bed. Three of the wheelchair-friendly rooms have twin beds. Each accessible room has a bed which can have the head- and foot of the bed adjusted at an incline. Amenities such as a safe, coffee machine, mini fridge, and other essentials are positioned within easy reach for wheelchair users. The accessible bathrooms include grab rails on both sides of the toilet, a bathtub, and a shower with a built-in seat. Dining options include the wheelchair-accessible WE ARE EDN restaurant and the ground-floor LOT61 café. LuminAir rooftop bar is also wheelchair-friendly, including a disabled toilet on the top floor. The hotel’s fitness centre and various conference rooms are also threshold-free. Underground parking is available at Parking Centrum Oosterdok for a daily fee. DoubleTree by Hilton Amsterdam Centraal Station | Oosterdoksstraat 4, Centrum Josephine Rees is the founder of Able Amsterdam , a website about wheelchair-friendly places and activities in Amsterdam. For more information, follow Josephine on Instagram and check out the Able Amsterdam website. Josephine Rees Josephine Rees is British-Dutch and the founder of Able Amsterdam. New in Town: Winter 2025 | I amsterdam Skip to main content Discover Amsterdam Live, Work and Study Meetings and Conventions Business English Discover Amsterdam What's on See and do Travel and stay City Card and tickets Discover Amsterdam What's on in Amsterdam New in Town: Winter 2025 (December) Image from Bar-Grill Marathonweg New in Town: Winter 2025 (December) Updated 3 December 2025 at 13:27 Written by Tom Flanagan Welcome to the winter edition of our New in Town series, our seasonal guide to the newest spots for food, drink and more. This season’s newest eateries take heart in the cold, as cosy bistros, Georgian fare and bakeries stave off the winter chill. CENTRUM Editor’s Pick: Sering Centraal Best for: community eats One of the best parts of winter is the community it fosters - after all, the cold brings people together like few things can. And a lot of that coming together is around the dining table. De Sering, which has run a community space and kitchen out near Sloterdijk, is making its central debut with a new outpost at Mediamatic in what’s set to be the centre’s newest communal hub. The menu is entirely vegan and the focus is really on fostering community with free meals for Stadspas holders to a donation-based dinner for all. Lunch is Mon-Fri and priced at €7.50, with a choice of two soups and two mains, best enjoyed with Sering Centraal’s waterside views. And only a 10-minute walk from Central Station, this could well be the centre’s best value and beautiful spot. Sering Centraal | open Mon-Fri | price range €-€€ | Dijksgracht 6 Amra Best for: indulgence Nothing says comfort food quite like bread and cheese. And Amra, which just opened in the Jordaan, brings the rich and indulgent dishes of Georgian cuisine to this corner of Amsterdam. Dumplings, orange wine and khachapuri (bread boats filled with molten chees, butter and an egg yolk) are a surefire way to warm you up and satisfy whatever wintry cravings might have taken hold. Amra | open Tue-Sun, 17:00-22:00 | price range €€-€€€ | Eerste Anjeliersdwarsstraat 6 Little Bonfire Best for: Retro snugness Gather round the fire at this snug haunt near the Bloemenmarkt. Self-described as Amsterdam’s downtown living room, there’s a hint of Mad Men here with its plush interior, rich mahogany panelling and leather bar seating. Comfort food lines the menu here as dishes like pan-fried sea bass, mushroom bourguigno and flat-iron chicken star. There’s also a roster of selected wines and classic cocktails which make it easy to while away an afternoon and an evening snug under the warm lighting. Little Bonfire | open all week, times vary | price range €€-€€€ | Keizersgracht 449 OOST Hagen Oost Best for: Scandi-chic coffee An espresso bar by way of Copenhagen, this coffee spot in Watergraafsmeer stands out – and not just because of its forest-green coloured exterior. The setting is pretty grand – all geometric-patterned flooring, bare brick walls and a long, floral-printed coffee counter – but don’t be discouraged, it’s just (good) coffee after all. Grab yourself an espresso, inspired by the serene coffee tasting Copenhagen does so well; a maximal experience dressed up in minimalism. Hagen Oost | open all week, 07:30-18:00 on weekdays, 08:30-18:00 on weekends | price range €-€€ | Mideenweg 59 Café Bica Best for: whitewashed escapism Should you be looking to cling to summer or draw it closer already, Café Bica can help. Situated along the Amstel River, just along from the owner's other venture Bam Boa, this sunlit space is perfect for those blue-skied winter days. A white-washed interior is simple but keeps the light filtered through, and the coffee and freshly baked pastries help keep you there. Stylish and undoubtedly a spot that’ll draw even the most reluctant De Pijp folk across the river, Bica looks to prove that the Wessperzijde really is the Amsterdam Riviera. Café Bica | open daily 08:00 - 18:00 | price range €-€€ | Weesperzijde 44 NOORD Camarat Best for: candle-lit wine Low-lit and luxurious, Camarat is a winter spot if ever there was one. Along the ever-happening Gedempt Hamerkanaal and right next to Amsterdam’s urban winery Chateau, the geometric shelves lit up by candles and floor-to-ceiling windows combine an indoor and outdoor feel. Yet even with the light, Camarat feels intimate; perhaps it’s the rich, brown textiles and furniture that does it, or the menu which spans wild duck and delicate skate (fish). Either way, come here for the kind of hushed nights winters are made for. Camarat | open Wed-Sun, opening times vary | price range €€-€€€ | Gedempt Hamerkanaal 4 Barossa Best for: bistro classics Cosy bistro fare almost never goes amiss, and add in a waterside view and you've got a perfect spot. That's Barossa, the latest spot to open in NDSM, channelling chic modernity in decor with comforting, seasonal fare on the menu. Run by the chef behind Peruvian fusion restaurant Nazka, it's no frills food here; from Caesar salads to market fish, roasted poussin and greens, plus bavette with peppercorn sauce. It's all prepared with panache from the open kitchen, and with a well-sourced wine menu and a special burger Friday deal, you'll find both class and comfort. Barossa | open Tue - Sat: 6pm - 10pm | price range €€-€€€ | Werfkade 39 WEST The Jollof Club Best for: flavour and comfort A staple of West African cuisine, jollof rice arrives in the neighbourhood in the form of Jollof Club. Named after the region’s most well-known dish, Jollof Club is a celebration of West African, serving up smoked jollof rice alongside other specials like soya chicken and rice pancakes drizzled in Scotchh Bonnet sauce. A delicious and savoury culinary experience, Jollof Club marks another chapter in De Baarsje’s expansive food journey. The Jollof Club | Open Wed–Sun, Sun Lunch only | price range €€-€€€ | Hoofdweg 141 Cheeky Best for: anytime coffee The appeal’s in the name at this brand new coffee spot in Westerpark. You'll find good brews, good tunes and good atmosphere here in this cosy space that's as much about the music as it is the coffee. Keep an eye out for special pop-ups and collaborations, which they do throughout the season and has included thai burgers and ADE dj specials. Either way, it’s a spot to hide from the cold and get communal in. Cheeky | open Tue-Fri 08:00-16:00, Sa-Su 08:00-16:30 | price range €-€€ | Fannius scholtenstraat 26H ZUID Sol Coffee Bar Best for: living room feels Everywhere wants to be a living room of Amsterdam but few actually succeed in balancing that low-key, relaxed almost effortless look-and-feel with the well-oiled machine of a good establishment. Sol makes a very respectable go at being a place that will stick around – a brocante-style space that pairs comfy seating, coffee and plenty of light to good effect. You won’t have to look far for home comforts here - the speculoos bun will do that if the apple and caramel pie hasn’t provided that already. There’s a warmth here that’ll keep you going through the season, and a no laptop policy means yes, chatting to other locals is encouraged. Sol | open Wed-Sun, 09:00-18:00 | price range €-€€ | Tweede Sweelinckstraat 6 Gorgo Lunchroom Best for: Anatolian goodness Born out of the homeland of its founders and the notion of in betweens, Gorgo Lunchroom is a celebration of modern-day Anatolia. Taking inspiration from the range of cultures that call contemporary Turkey home, Gorgo Lunchroom has a little bit of everything. Coffee, fermented drinks and sandwiches, but it’s the specific flavours on show that make it interesting. Like tahin and honey, which in their words, is “a gooey cheese melt of kaşar and Welsh cheddar, topped with tahini, honey, preserved unripe green figs, and roasted hazelnuts”, orkavurmalı : slow-roasted beef, salça, fresh thyme, kaşar and pecorino. Oh and the cookies are good too. Gorgo Lunchroom | open Tue-Sun, 08:30-17:00 | price range €-€€ | Staringplein 22 In case you missed it Boon & de Koot Cosy, bistro feels by the creators of De Zoldering and Lof wine bar, this one’s for the Dutch and French food lovers and anyone who just wants comforting dishes and wine. Amsterdam Culture Guide (December 2025) | I amsterdam Skip to main content Discover Amsterdam Live, Work and Study Meetings and Conventions Business English Discover Amsterdam What's on See and do Travel and stay City Card and tickets Discover Amsterdam What's on in Amsterdam Culture Guide (December 2025) Image from Janus van den Eijnden Culture Guide (December 2025) Updated 1 December 2025 at 15:55 Written by Tom Flanagan December is here and now's the time to wrap up unfinished business and reset your cultural agenda. This month, wander through botanical gardens, take in light sculptures across the city, celebrate the season with a visit to the Christmas Circus and much more. Editor’s Pick: Hortus Winteravonden Image from Jan Jaap Hubeek Best for: plant lovers This winter, it’s time to get cosy at one of the world’s oldest botanical gardens, as the doors remain open until late for Hortus Winteravonden (Winter Evenings). Venture through the beautifully lit greenhouses – and the new Climate Greenhouse, which spans three climates around the world – as you discover ancient palms and tropical plants. Cuddle up by the campfire with a hot chocolate on the winter terrace and experience exclusive exhibitions featuring night-blooming flowers and much more. Hortus Winteravonden | 27-30 December & 2-3 January | Hortus Botanicus Amsterdam Light Festival Image from Janus van den Eijnden Best for: night owls The city’s annual light festival returns, this time under the theme of ‘Legacy’ and how we want to be remembered. To glimpse all the installations looking to capture what that means, you have a range of options. Opt for a cocktail cruise with one of the many canal companies or follow a self-guided 6.5km walking route that you can dip into at your own pace. Bring your winter coat, camera and a sense of awe. Amsterdam Light Festival | Until 18 January 2026 | city-wide The Nutcracker and the Mouse King at National Opera & Ballet Best for: festive nostalgia One of the season’s most celebrated shows returns to the National Opera & Ballet stage for a festive run. The Nutcracker and the Mouse King – a tale of an inanimate Nutcracker coming to life to fend off the evil Mouse King – takes ballet form this time as snow-flecked dancers in frosted attire glide across the winter stage. Choreographed and designed by Toer van Schayk, he was inspired by the drawings of artist Christiaan Andriessen (1777-1854), which provided a window into an Amsterdam of old. The Nutcracker and the Mouse King | 12 December 2025 – 2 January 2026 | National Opera & Ballet Derek Mitchell’s Double Dutch: Two at Meervaart Best for: searing cultural commentary Nobody gets the Dutch and the Americans (and even the Brits) better than Derek Mitchell. He’s best known for his live shows blending standup with cultural commentary, which are a tongue-in-cheek ode to his adopted homeland. Catch him at the Meervaart Theatre for his Double Dutch Two show, for searing comedy on what it means to be caught between cultures. Double Dutch | 8 December 2025 | Meervaart Theatre Surinamese Art in Transition at Museum Cobra Best for: inquisitive artists This past November marked 50 years of Surinamese independence. And Museum Cobra is commemorating that milestone with a special exhibition dedicated entirely to Surinamese Art. Around 24 artists and one collective will present their works on what Surinamese freedom means, depicting its past struggle, present change and future, with fashion, photography, paintings, installations, film, and performance art all on show. Wi Sranan. Surinamese Art in Transition | Until 1 March 2026 | Museum Cobra Winterparadijs at RAI Image from Het Amsterdamse Winterparadijs Best for: seasonal maximalism The RAI transforms into a winter wonderland in December with indoor and outdoor ice-skating rinks, parties in the Après-Ski Village, dining options galore and fairground rides overlooking the city. Tube across real (fake) snow, cross-country ski between the fir trees, roast marshmallows over a crackling fire, practice your curling skills or join in with a classic snowball fight. When it's all too much fun, head into the Winter Cinema for nostalgic festive classics. Winterparadijs | 17 December - 3 January | RAI World Christmas Circus at Carré Image from Koninklijk Theater Carré Best for: family outings For decades, the World Christmas Circus at Royal Theater Carré has been one of the most popular family outings during the festive period. Marvel at the flying trapeze artists, star clowns, enchanting costumes, horse whisperers, and daredevils as award-winning acts from the most prominent circus festivals worldwide join forces in one spectacular show for this 39th edition. World Christmas Circus | 17 December 2025 - 4 January 2026 | Carré Queer Christmas Market at Door Open Space Best for: non-traditionalists Christmas markets are everywhere in and around Amsterdam, but why not break with convention and tradition this year and head to the Queer Christmas Market? Meet 35+ queer entrepreneurs selling a range of vintage, art, food and drinks, with drag performances on show too. This is a chance to support queer makers, sort out your seasonal gifting and indulge in the festive spirit – plus the market donates €0.50 per ticket to a queer charity so there’s a good cause to support too. Queer Christmas Market | 13 December, 11:00-17:00 | Door Open Space Vivian Ammerlaan at Singer Laren Image from Vivian Ammerlaan Best for: intrepid travellers Get swept up in the dreamy, storm-coloured images of Vivian Ammerlaan whose photography of the Rocky Mountains is almost as good as visiting the region yourself. Inspired by her travels among the ridges, Amerlaan’s shots are haunting, spectral and effortlessly wintry. Bookend your trip with a visit to the on-site café for a cosy winter afternoon. Vivian Ammerlaan | until 18 January 2026 | Singer Laren Amsterdam, almost demolished at Grachtenmuseum Best for: urban history The Museum of Canals (Grachtenmuseum) is one of the city’s unsung heroes and its latest exhibition is proof of more quiet heroism. In Amsterdam, almost demolished, the tale of how the city maintained its historic architecture and centre in the face of a mass modernisation push takes centre stage. A tapestry of protest footage, maps and photography, the exhibition traces the people who helped preserve Amsterdam’s beauty – and it’s future. Amsterdam, almost demolished | until 28 March 2026 | Grachtenmuseum Tom Flanagan Culture Editor at iamsterdam.com covering online and print (I amsterdam magazine). likes: nostalgia and pastry. dislikes: overhead lighting. Top tips to beat the crowds at Amsterdam's attractions | I amsterdam Skip to main content Discover Amsterdam Live, Work and Study Meetings and Conventions Business English Discover Amsterdam What's on See and do Travel and stay City Card and tickets Discover Amsterdam See and do Top tips to beat the crowds in Amsterdam Image from Pauline Arkesteijn Top tips to beat the crowds in Amsterdam Updated 1 April 2025 at 14:12 Many of Amsterdam’s most famous attractions can get pretty busy at peak times but that doesn't mean you can't squeeze them into your travel itinerary. Follow the top 5 tips below to skip the ticket booth queues, avoid the biggest crowds and experience some of the city's highlights! Always plan and pre-book Image from Koen Smilde It’s great to wander around Amsterdam and enjoy whatever awaits you. But if you have the luxury of pre-booking tickets for museums and attractions , the most significant benefit is showing up when it suits you and avoiding the lines at the ticket booths (just be careful to follow the signs to the correct door). The I amsterdam City Card offers free entrance to many major museums. See all museums included in the I amsterdam City Card Venture into the greater Amsterdam Area Image from Creative bros Image from Koen Dijkstra Image from koen smilde Image from koen smilde Image from koen smilde Previous slide Next slide 1 / 5 Slide 1 of 5 Experience Amsterdam and its surroundings like a local when you follow our favourite day trips during all seasons. You’ll walk or cycle along cobblestone streets, nibble savoury snacks and soak up the art and culture that’s made Amsterdam's area famous. Explore the entire region with the convenient Amsterdam & Region Travel Ticket that offers unlimited transport by bus, tram, train, and metro beyond the city limits of Amsterdam. Time is on your side Image from Mirte Vreemann Image from Christian van der Kooy Previous slide Next slide 1 / 3 Slide 1 of 3 Remember that many museums in Amsterdam don't just stick to the nine-to-five routine! Here's our guide to art after dark: late opening museums in Amsterdam . The Van Gogh Museum is open every Friday evening until 21:00. Why not book your timeslot around 17:00 on a Friday? The museum is quieter as crowds disperse for dinner, allowing more personal and precious moments to enjoy the artworks. The Rijksmuseum (free with the I amsterdam City Card ) notes that April, May and August are the busiest months and that Friday, Saturday and Sunday are the most popular days. As such, waiting times can be around 30 minutes. But if you’d really like a bit more space to enjoy the museum, their advice is to either arrive in time for opening (9:00) or at the end of the afternoon (after 15:00). There’s always great demand to experience the famous canal-side Anne Frank House . Throughout the year it’s common to see queues stretching around the block, often with waiting times of 45 minutes (up to 2 hours at peak times). The advice from the Anne Frank House is to purchase your ticket in advance, but it’s also well worth stopping by for an evening visit – from April until August, the museum is open until 22:00. The Stedelijk Museum is open till 21:00 on Fridays, and the photography museum Foam is open till 21:00 on Thursdays and Fridays. Always check the websites of your favourite museums for extra opening hours and special events. See the city by bike Image from Robin Utrecht Taking to two wheels and having the city pass you by feels especially ‘Amsterdam’. But if you’re not a frequent cyclist and don’t know your way, the crowded streets and the hustle and bustle around hotspots like Dam Square and Leidseplein can feel intimidating. Here's a guide to cycling in Amsterdam for some tips on getting around. And if the mere thought of cycling amidst cars and trams sets your pulse racing, check out the variety of cycleseeing routes into the countryside . Within 20 minutes of the city centre, you can be in the spacious fields and off to windmills, traditional farms and clog makers. Get off the beaten path Image from Koen Smilde Photography Image from Koen Smilde Previous slide Next slide 1 / 2 Slide 1 of 2 There are many alternatives to Amsterdam's top attractions, from quirky art galleries to cosy neighbourhood coffee joints. For the most local experience, head out of the Canal Ring into the city's vibrant neighbourhoods , from leafy Oud-West and De Baarsjes to vibrant Noord and NDSM (just a short ferry ride across the IJ. We've written in-depth guides for each neighbourhood, so you're sure you will find something completely new. And be sure to check out our cultural and culinary hidden gems . These insider tips and guides will get you feeling like a real Amsterdammer . Nature and active in Oost | I amsterdam Skip to main content Discover Amsterdam Live, Work and Study Meetings and Conventions Business English Discover Amsterdam What's on See and do Travel and stay City Card and tickets Discover Amsterdam Explore Amsterdam Neighbourhoods of Amsterdam Oost Nature and active in Oost Image from Merijn Roubroeks Nature and active in Oost Updated 27 February 2025 at 13:05 Amongst the play areas and lush parks, greenery is to be found everywhere in Amsterdam-Oost. Take a paddle board along the River Amstel, relax by the water in Flevopark or test your balance with an adventure sport like windsurfing or rock climbing. Here’s our roundup of the best spots to get active and outdoors in Oost. Oosterpark Image from Jan de Ridder Image from Jan de Ridder Previous slide Next slide 1 / 2 Slide 1 of 2 From cultural festivals such as Keti Koti to picnic opportunities overlooking the water, Oosterpark offers something for everyone. Perhaps one of the city’s most stunning parks, this beautiful green space has a paddling pool for children to splash in, plenty of areas for sporty activities (like rollerblading and jogging) and various outdoor sculptures to admire. There’s even a bandstand where dance classes take place, and it is one of the few parks in Amsterdam where you can still barbecue, making it an excellent option for warm summer evenings. Park Frankendael Image from Merijn Roubroeks In the 17th and 18th centuries, dozens of imposing summer residences owned by wealthy Amsterdammers lined the streets of Amsterdam Oost. Today, only Huize Frankendael remains. The large garden around Huize Frankendael was partly opened up as a pleasure garden in the 19th century and was later used as a city nursery. Today Park Frankendael is a popular neighbourhood hangout and the art and culture garden of Oost. Within the park, you’ll find Restaurant De Kas situated within a giant greenhouse which sources ingredients from its very own kitchen garden. Flevopark Image from Koen Smilde Surrounded by vast swathes of water, the unique location of Flevopark makes it the ideal location to spot wildlife and lesser-seen plant species. Strolling through this lush green area, you’ll see sights you don't often encounter in Amsterdam, including rare birds like the kingfisher who lives by the lake near Distillerij 't Nieuwe Diep . It's the ideal spot for dog-walking, picnicking and sunbathing along with the trendy residents of Amsterdam Oost. Looking for even more adventure? Flevopark also boasts a delightful open-air swimming pool, Flevoparkbad , and the largest adventure playground in Amsterdam: Jeugdland . Along the Amstel Image from Koen Smilde Amsterdam-Oost is flanked by the broad Amstel River, which winds its way South into some spectacular green countryside. There’s an excellent Amstel River cycle route which passes the ornamental gardens and allotments of Tuinpark Amstelglorie , then heads along the Duivendrecht polder in the direction of the historic village Ouderkerk aan de Amstel. The Amstel is also an excellent spot for rowing, boating or trying your hand at Supping and canoeing. Check out the rental centres at Kano & Sup Amsterdam and SUP rental . One of the numerous rowing clubs in Amsterdam is The Berlagebrug Rowing Center , directly on the River Amstel which offers classes, private lessons and tours. Surfcenter IJburg Image from Strand IJburg Within easy reach of the city centre and Amsterdam-Oost, IJburg is a watersports paradise. Surfcenter IJburg offers windsurf classes for all levels, including those who have never stepped onto a board and those who want to train to be an instructor. All equipment is provided, and Blijburg Beach, where the clubhouse is situated, is the perfect spot to hang loose and watch that glorious Dutch sunset. Ultimate frisbee Image from Husky - CC BY 4.0 Ultimate frisbee is one of the fastest-growing team sports in the world; a fun an accessible game where points are scored by throwing the frisbee to a team member in the end zone. Amsterdam is getting in on the fun, with more and more ultimate frisbee fans in town. Amsterdam Ultimate Club in Oost is one of the main clubs in town and their outdoor training sessions take place at Sportpark Drieburg. Of course, you can also read up on the rules online, grab a frisbee from a toy shop and head to the nearest park with a bunch of friends. Jaap Eden Ice Rink Image from Jaap Eden Baan The colossal Jaap Eden skating rink, open from October to March, is the go-to spot for amateurs and pros alike to develop their skills. Budding speedskaters can make use of the 400-metre track, which allows you to glide through quite a few laps in your own lane without having to swerve for children. But don’t worry, if you haven’t nailed your double axels yet, there’s an indoor rink and a beginners corner. Jaap is the home turf of the Amstel Tijgers, so be sure to check the schedule for ice hockey matches, discos and a variety of other public activities. De Vergulden Eenhoorn Image from Vergulden Eenhoorn If you’re looking for more gentle exercise, perhaps the kind you can do with a glass of wine in hand, look no further than De Vergulden Eenhoorn . This historic country pub conceals one of Amsterdam’s best-kept secrets: its very own jeu de boules pitch. If a quick round of petanque is still too much exertion for you, why not lounge around in the deckchairs of the beautiful secluded garden as drinks and snacks are brought to you? Restaurants and bars in Oost | I amsterdam Skip to main content Discover Amsterdam Live, Work and Study Meetings and Conventions Business English Discover Amsterdam What's on See and do Travel and stay City Card and tickets Discover Amsterdam Explore Amsterdam Neighbourhoods of Amsterdam Oost Restaurants and bars in Oost Restaurants and bars in Oost Updated 6 December 2025 at 10:22 From innovative plant-based food to fine-dining in a greenhouse, the food and drink scene in Amsterdam Oost screams innovation and creativity. In this culturally diverse district, you’ll find all manner of exciting restaurants offering modern takes on various cuisines. There's also a wealth of breweries, cocktail bars, a fantastic range of coffee and brunch hotspots and some of the best falafel and roti in town. Coffee and lunch hotspots Image from Rum Baba Amsterdam Oost is a coffee-lover's paradise with what seems like a new espresso bar or café to try every day: The beans are roasted on-site at Rum Baba, and you can taste the difference. 4850 is a fine-dining restaurant by night, serving buns and Scandinavian-roasted coffee for sipping on the terrace by day. Coffee Bru is the spot to grab a tasty filter coffee (roasted by Rum Baba), buttery scones or a slice of toasted banana bread. Also check out: The Cottage , tHUIS aan de AMSTEL or Bakhuys to get your caffeine fix. Bar Bachrach Image from Anouk Erisman Image from Tom Flanagan Previous slide Next slide 1 / 2 Slide 1 of 2 Lovers of modern Middle Eastern food, look no further! Bar Bachrach, located on Javaplein, is heavily inspired by the cuisines of Lebanon, Tel Aviv, and Barcelona. Expect an elevated presentation and a well-varied menu filled with inventive takes, such as the liver pate challah toast with pear chutney, shish boreks with pine nuts and yoghurt, and much more. Highlights include smoky eggplant with pomegranate molasses, lamb kofta served with tahini and pickled vegetables, and their signature freekeh salad with herbs, nuts, and citrus dressing - each dish offering a bold, balanced mix of flavours that feel both comforting and fresh. Badhuis Image from WV Productions Every neighbourhood has a spot that everyone considers the spot. In the east of Amsterdam, that place was long considered the Badhuis , a former bathhouse on the Javaplein that functioned as a place for the predominantly working-class locals to wash, meet and get together. Now it's an all-day café and brasserie, serving international fare for the community. The space is arguably the primary draw, but then so is the menu, from coffee and croissants in the morning and sandwiches in the day to classic bistro mains like mushroom ravioli and steak frites, all paired with wine, cocktails or a custom Badhuis beer. Brouwerij 't IJ Image from Koen Smilde This brewery bar under a windmill is a beer-drinking institution in Amsterdam. Brouwerij 't IJ was one of the city's first independent microbreweries, and you'll see locals proudly sporting t-shirts with their iconic ostrich logo all over town. The large enclosed terrace will be packed year-round with punters sampling classic brews like the IJwit, Flink Pale Ale and Natte Dubbel, along with new experimental creations freshly poured from the taps. You'll also find a great menu of Dutch and Belgian snacks such as ox-sausage, pickles and cheese boards to keep your stomach lined during a merry afternoon of beer tasting. Café Wu Image from Jois Ang French and Chinese food may not be the most obvious pairing, but that's precisely what makes Café Wu so inventive and enticing. Along the market street Dapperstraat, this bistro combines the best of Chinese food with the haute cuisine of French gastronomy. Here, you'll find a gorgeous open kitchen, a selection of wine bottles (over 170 to choose from), and a chef's and à la carte menu filled with some of the prettiest plates of food you'll find in Oost. Cantonese roasted duck gets a facelift in a dish of duck breast, Russian cabbage and wrapped in puff pastry, while bone marrow serves as one of the bistro's flagship dishes, com boned with veal tongue, crispy onions, chilli oil and rice. And there's even entertainment after the food from 22:00, where vinyls help set a more ambient and intimate mood. Local Dealer Image from Local Dealer Image from Local Dealer Previous slide Next slide 1 / 2 Slide 1 of 2 One of Amsterdam's best hotspots for authentic Mexican street food , Local Dealer is a colourful diner on the Dappermarkt with a straight-to-the-point concept. Choose from a selection of ceviches, antojitos (little snacks) or tacos loaded up with everything from carne asada (grilled steak) to barbacoa lamb or Holy Pastor (their delicious vegan option with grilled pineapple). Or drop by on a Sunday for their brunch event to munch on huevos rancheros, breakfast burritos and chilaquiles with a bloody mary in hand as DJs spin funky tunes. On warm evenings, mezcals, margaritas, micheladas and bottles of Modelo beer fly off the bar towards the lively outdoor terrace - we'd recommend reserving a spot if the sun is out. Ode aan de Amstel Image from Ode aan de Amstel Perched on the Amstel with a waterside patio and unparalleled river views, Ode aan de Amstel is a new all-day dining spot for unusual but delightful dishes with an Asian twist. Dive into scallops with passionfruit foam with a wakame and pak choi salad or hand-cut steak tartare with green curry cream and matchstick fries. The tandoori-rubbed chicken and prawn skewers served with sticky lemongrass rice cubes, garlicky yoghurt and ponzu dip are also not to be missed. Tip: pick a fair-weather day to visit, as the terrace here is terrific! Krux Brouwwerf Image from KRUX Brewed in the smallest vats in Amsterdam, Krux Brouwwerf' s beer goes straight to tap and into your glass. This small-scale set-up allows Krux to experiment with tastes: you will find fourteen beers on tap that change regularly. Relax in the spacious beer garden as you quench your thirst with a fresh pint of IPA or settle into Remy's Corner inside with a platter of bitterballen to share. turbo & Buurtcafe De Tros Image from Lotte Bergman Midcentury decor, ambient lighting, teak furniture, and a gourmet croquette are just some things you'll find at all-day café turbo . The sister venture to Buurtcafe De Tros next door, turbo, is the more low-key sibling of the two, a place for breakfast, lunch, dinner, and everything in between. As a result, the menu is far-reaching, with popular choices like steak tartare, tuna, and chicken legs, all made with seasonal ingredients. There are sandwiches for lunch, too, ranging from meatball subs to katsu fish sando. But the star dish is the broodje kroket , a Dutch classic given a new twist. An oxtail croquette topped with remoulade sauce on a brioche bun, this is arguably Amsterdam's most luxe take on an old favourite. Beyond the food, you'll find great coffee from Friedhats roastery in Amsterdam and an extensive wine list, too. Wilde Zwijnen Image from Wilde Zwijnen The chefs at Wilde Zwijnen have been giving authentic Dutch dishes a contemporary facelift for over a decade now. As much as possible, the kitchen sources high-quality seasonal products from small-scale farmers in the surrounding region. Delve into a three or four-course menu which encompasses a range of creative dishes - herring caviar, tomato granita, duck stew, razor shell clams and asparagus ice cream - which showcase the very best of modern Dutch cuisine. Each plate is thoughtfully composed, balancing rustic Dutch roots with refined technique and a touch of playful surprise. Counter On one of Oost’s most vaunted (and once voted best) streets, you’ll find Counter . A veggie-focused deli in the day and wine bar at night, it hits all the markers for an all-day neighbourhood spot at exceptionally good value. In the afternoon, you’ll find a much sought-after but infrequently found lunch menu – a soup, sandwich and sweet all for €10. Come the evenings, it’s all low lights, wine and the family meal – meaning a large portion of quality food like nasi and tempeh – for €12. You’ll be hard pushed to find better value for money paired with quality and atmosphere – it’s cosy and has a string-light lit terrace – and in 2025, that’s exactly the kind of restaurant we need in Amsterdam. Introduction VisitCopenhagen.com and the connected social media channels under the same brand are owned and run by Wonderful Copenhagen, the official tourist organization in the Copenhagen region. All content on VisitCopenhagen and its social media channels is editorial, chosen and written by our editorial staff in alignment with Wonderful Copenhagen’s strategy and VisitCopenhagen’s communication strategy. Our main focus is to fulfil the travellers’ needs for the benefit of the destination. Strategic reason VisitCopenhagen’s communication strategy is founded on principles supporting sustainable tourism and attracting people from abroad who share the same mindset. The three main pillars of this effort are seasonal spread , geographical spread, and sustainable behaviour . On top of that, our storytelling is built around four strengths that make Copenhagen stand out, are difficult to copy for competing destinations, and that guests find attractive. Our four themes are gastronomy , outdoor city life , architecture and design , and culture and art . According to this, at least one or more of these defined strengths must be present in each component of the overall narrative we built around Copenhagen as a travel destination. Editorial freedom and independence VisitCopenhagen is run on the principle of editorial freedom. We are not paid to put certain content on the site. The editorial decisions are solely made following the strategies of Wonderful Copenhagen and VisitCopenhagen. The purpose of VisitCopenhagen.com is not to be a complete directory of things to experience in Copenhagen but to transmit a narrative that can inspire travellers and convey a rightful, authentic image of Copenhagen as a travel destination. For that reason, we reserve the right to pass on stories, points of interest, etc., even though they may align with our communication strategy. Safety | Visit Copenhagen Skip to main content The official guide to Copenhagen Beyond Copenhagen Copenhagen Card See & do Eat & drink City areas Planning Beyond Copenhagen My Trip Search Add to my trip Print Share Safety Photo : Martin Heiberg Copenhagen is in general a safe city to visit. But just like in any other city, you should take certain precautions. Safety in general In addition to following the official travel guidelines of your own national authorities, you can consult Danish Police here . Christiania The area is loved by many but has been a turning point for strong debate due to illegal drug dealings, which have also been subject to safety concerns for visitors. The community and authorities have worked together to improve safety and address criminal activities. (Danish legislation prohibits the dealing, buying, and possessing of illegal substances). On April 6, 2024, the residents of Christiania took a significant step by digging up the cobblestones on “Pusher Street”. This act was a symbolic gesture to mark the end of the open drug market in the area. It is advised not to search out Christiania for any sort of illegal substances. Pickpockets love distractions Photo : Thomas Rousing Around Copenhagen Central Station you should pay extra attention to pickpockets. The area around City Hall Square and the beginning of Strøget (the pedestrian street) is very busy, and also an area to be aware of thieves. Each summer, Copenhagen Municipality, in collaboration with Copenhagen Police, run a campaign warning against pickpockets. They use a variety of distractions and tactics to relieve victims of their personal items. Please ask yourself the following questions: Are you aware of your valuables in a crowd? Are your phone and money safely stored? When you pay with a card, do you always cover your pin code? Crowded areas Strøget , City Hall Square and Gothersgade can be crowded areas by night – especially during weekends. Fake police On a few rare occasions, tourists have been scammed by fake police officers. The victims have either paid on-the-spot fines for "breaking the law" or have been frisked and unknowingly robbed. If contacted by a police officer, demand to see legit identification. You can always contact the police by calling 114. In case of urgent matters, call 112. Looking for more inspiration for your trip? Check out these guides. Eating out: When organic is the logical choice, not a luxury The New Nordic Cuisine put Copenhagen on the culinary world map. It also sparked a revolution with its focus on local, organic ingredients in season. Today, this focus is maybe stronger than ever among restaurants in Copenhagen, and you’ll find many climate-friendly and organic eating options in all price ranges from noma, and Geranium to Reffen street food market. In Copenhagen, buying organic produce is not considered a luxury, but merely logical. Organic food make up 24% of the total food sale in Copenhagen, and 88% of the food consumption in the City of Copenhagen’s public institutions is organic. Add to my trip Organic restaurants Great restaurants catering to all tastes and budgets. Common for these places is their strong focus on quality, taste and organic and/or bio dynamic food and wine. Add to my trip Restaurants that take sustainability to another level Organic produce is not enough if restaurants want to minimize their carbon footprint. Growing their own veggies, re-using resources and re-thinking energy consumption into all processes are all green initiatives that set these super sustainable (and really delicious) restaurants apart. Add to my trip Best vegetarian and vegan restaurants Looking for vegetarian or vegan food? Try out Copenhagen's restaurants that are either entirely vegetarian and vegan or are guaranteed to offer vegetarian and / or vegan courses next to the meat courses. Podcast: Insider's Guide to Copenhagen | Visit Copenhagen Skip to main content The official guide to Copenhagen Beyond Copenhagen Copenhagen Card See & do Eat & drink City areas Planning Beyond Copenhagen My Trip Search Add to my trip Print Share Podcast: Insider's Guide to Copenhagen Photo : Mellanie Gandø Whether you're a Copenhagen local or visiting, you will discover plenty of new spots in this podcast! Radio and television host Esben Bjerre joins different Copenhageners in their favourite activities, places to eat, where they bring their friends, and many hidden gems around the city. Listen on Apple Podcast , Spotify or on your favourite podcast app . Mark Tanggaard Classic culture, deep-rooted history, and fresh seafood Rhea Leman came to Copenhagen in 1976, and was immediately in love with the city. She felt safe regardless of where and when she was, which was a big contrast to her native New York City. She particularly enjoys how history is present on every street in Copenhagen, and she loves to stroll through the parks and museums and indulge in delicious food in restaurants. Listen to Rhea's guide here Mark Tanggaard Winter bathing, ancient artifacts and retro coolness Justine Bell is an architect, and was educated in London. Orignally from Cape Town in South Africa, Copenhagen is very different from what she has been used to before. Here, she is close to an ocean, less rowdy than the Atlantic Ocean. The walkable and bike-friendly city, combined with the rapid change of seasons, has Justine fall in love with Copenhagen and call it her home. Listen to Justine's guide here Daniel Rasmussen Food from abroad, crispy wines and retro arcade gaming A decade ago, New York chef Nick Curtin and his Danish wife decided to move to Copenhagen, and he has been in love with the city ever since. He found coming to Denmark fascinating because it differed from his life in the United States. He states, "Copenhagen is very international, but still very Danish!" Living in Copenhagen has taught him many things about himself, such as how he interacts with people and how he thinks about food. He emphasises the green spaces and the international food scene, where people have come from their home country and found a space for their native foods in Copenhagen. Listen to Nicks' guide here Mark Tanggaard Deer safari, a royal hunting palace and Danish design galore Inan Isik, a Turkish fashion designer, might get Danes better than most - at least what the trends in Danish fashions are! Having worked for both GANNI, Marlene Birger and Bestseller, she has a finger on the pulse regarding what is trendy. Join Inan as she shows Esben where she spends his time in Beyond Copenhagen. It is only a short train ride from multiple stations in Copenhagen, and with many trains per hour, the destinations are easily reachable. Listen to Inans' guide here Mark Tanggaard Architecture, Italian food and waterfronts When Enlai Hooi was looking to relocate from Australia, he knew he wanted to go to Europe, and "by luck" ended up in Copenhagen. With an Irish-Chinese background, he feels that he blends perfectly into the multicultural Copenhagen, where "nobody cares where you are from." As an architect, the medieval buildings that almost intertwine with each other never cease to amaze him, along with the water that glues the city together. Listen to Enlai's guide here Mark Tanggaard Nature, tranquillity and a uniquely preserved village Kriti Prajapati had never heard of Copenhagen when her husband accepted a job there. Seven years later, she has now shifted her career from engineer to comedian, where she mostly looks at Danes from the outside and lovingly pokes fun at them. She feels safe in Copenhagen and connected to nature here, even though Dragør can be hard to pronounce! Listen to Kriti's guide here Mark Tanggaard Blixen, Shakespeare and maritime Elsinore When Keri was out celebrating a friend in New Zealand, she got hungry and started to chat with a Danish tourist with a pizza. The rest is history, and now she works as an author in Denmark, living, observing and writing about the Danish way of life Listen to Keri's guide here Mark Tanggaard Danish design, wine and kayaking Dressed in almost exactly the same outfit, HAY designer Sam shows Esben a more design-oriented Copenhagen. As Sam has noticed, design, art, and furniture are such an essential part of Danish history and heritage, which Copenhagen reflects. The architecture, the food quality, the design, and the atmosphere are all of the best quality—both on land and in water! Listen to Sam's guide here Mark Tanggaard Bikes, coffee and urban spaces When Aldo fell in love with a Danish woman, he begged her to bring him to Copenhagen. When he arrived, it was snowy and windy, and people were still on their bikes. Flabbergasted by the stubbornness of Danes, combined with his own passion for cycling, he knew he had to move here. For Aldo, the bike equals freedom. With freedom and the love of Copenhagen, he has found a balance that keeps him relaxed. Listen to Aldo's guide here Mark Tanggaard Art, wellness and a spectacular view According to Mamie Beth Cary, Copenhagen is a "small dog with a big dog mentality." Born in central London, she moved to Copenhagen in 2016 and works as Director of von Bartha. Copenhagen has a great art scene where Mamie quickly discovered a simple life was possible. She says, that there is " this kind of charm in Copenhagen" where life is more simple, there is more quality, the streets are clean, and where water and height combine with the landscape. Listen to Mamie's guide here Mark Tanggaard Adrenaline rushes and exotic food When Rosio Sanchez first came to Copenhagen, it was to work as a pastry chef for Noma; She actually heard about Noma, before she heard about Copenhagen! Now, Copenhagen is home. To her, Copenhagen is a city that "has more or less everything" and feels like a breath of fresh air. The walkable city with cycle paths everywhere keeps you active and as she said, "it's is a special city that changes how you are." Listen to Rosio's guide here Mark Tanggaard Beer, bathing and solo traveling Laura Hall visited Copenhagen for the first time as a solo traveller. Later, she moved back and thought she would be here for two years. After six months, Laura and her husband looked at each other and decided the easy Copenhagen lifestyle was for them. She feels that Copenhagen is safe, notably for women travelling solo, and that Danes are kind and caring. And the weather? Laura has taken the Danish saying “There's no such thing as bad weather, only unsuitable clothing” to heart! Listen to Laura's guide here Mellanie Gandø Kids in the city When Annie Samples's husband got a job offer in his dream city, Copenhagen, the Texas-born mother of four packed everything up and made the move despite never having set foot on Danish soil. Fortunately, she fell in love with Copenhagen and to her, this is now home. After the initial cultural shock, for instance, coming to terms with the Danish stroller practice, she and her family fell in love with the architecture, flowers, bakeries, and much more. Listen to Annie's guide here Mellanie Gandø Drinks and Danish Smørrebrød When Harry Bell wanted to expand his horizons and leave Italy, his friend told him, "Do you want to be in the place where everything already happened or do you want to be in the place where everybody needs to be?" Harry went to Copenhagen because he knew it as a place with a strong food scene. His plan was to stay for a year - and eight years later, he is still here. According to himself, he has lost his heart to Copenhagen. Day trips from Copenhagen Copenhagen, a vibrant capital city, offers a wealth of experiences. But just beyond its bustling streets lies a diverse landscape brimming with history, natural beauty, and charming towns. Embarking on a day trip from Copenhagen is the perfect way to immerse yourself in the authentic Danish experience, discovering hidden gems and creating lasting memories. Why Choose a Day Trip from Copenhagen? Easy Access: Denmark's compact size and excellent transportation network make exploring beyond Copenhagen incredibly easy. Whether you prefer scenic train journeys, comfortable bus rides, or the freedom of a rental car, you'll find convenient options to reach your chosen destination. Variety of Experiences: From majestic castles and Viking history to dramatic coastlines and serene countryside, the areas surrounding Copenhagen offer a diverse range of attractions. Whether you're a history buff, a nature lover, an art enthusiast, or simply seeking relaxation, there's a perfect day trip waiting for you. Escape the City: While Copenhagen is a fantastic city, sometimes you need a break from the urban buzz. A day trip allows you to escape the city's hustle and bustle and reconnect with nature, explore quieter towns, and experience a different pace of life. Rich Cultural Heritage: Denmark's history and culture are deeply intertwined with its landscapes and towns. Day trips offer a unique opportunity to delve deeper into Danish heritage, visiting historical sites, exploring museums, and experiencing local traditions. Create Lasting Memories: Whether you're traveling solo, as a couple, with family, or with friends, a day trip from Copenhagen is a chance to create unforgettable memories. These experiences will add another dimension to your Danish adventure. Discover Copenhagen's countryside Copenhagen's vibrant energy is undeniable, but the true heart of Denmark often lies in its tranquil countryside. Just a short journey from the capital, a world of rolling fields, charming villages, and picturesque coastlines awaits. Embarking on a countryside day trip from Copenhagen offers a refreshing escape, allowing you to experience the authentic beauty and peaceful rhythm of rural Danish life. Immerse Yourself in Nature's Embrace: Rolling Landscapes & Open Skies: Leave behind the city's concrete jungle and breathe in the fresh, clean air of the Danish countryside. Vast fields of golden wheat, vibrant green pastures dotted with grazing cows, and expansive blue skies create a sense of tranquility and connection with nature. Coastal Delights & Seaside Charm: Denmark's coastline is never far away, and countryside day trips often lead to charming fishing villages, sandy beaches, and dramatic cliffs overlooking the sea. Enjoy the salty air, the sound of crashing waves, and the picturesque beauty of the Danish coastline. Forests & Lakes: Discover hidden forests perfect for hiking and exploring, or relax by the serene shores of crystal-clear lakes. The Danish countryside offers a variety of natural landscapes, providing opportunities for outdoor activities and peaceful contemplation. Experience Rural Life & Local Charm: Charming Villages & Quaint Towns: Explore idyllic villages with colorful houses, cobblestone streets, and friendly locals. Discover hidden gems, browse local shops, and experience the authentic charm of rural Danish life. Local Produce & Culinary Delights: The Danish countryside is a haven for food lovers. Copenhagen Weather - A Guide To All Seasons | Visit Copenhagen Skip to main content The official guide to Copenhagen Beyond Copenhagen Copenhagen Card See & do Eat & drink City areas Planning Beyond Copenhagen My Trip Search Add to my trip Print Share Copenhagen Weather - A Guide To All Seasons Photo : VisitCopenhagen The weather in Copenhagen changes seasonally and each season brings its own unique twist on the Copenhagen experience. So, whether you're into sun-drenched adventures or cozy café crawls, let's break down what each season has in store. Table of contents: Winter weather in Copenhagen Spring weather in Copenhagen Summer weather in Copenhagen Autumn weather in Copenhagen Average monthly temperatures Average monthly sea water temperatures Winter Weather in Copenhagen Winter in Copenhagen allows you to bring out your inner viking by diving into the ice cold, yet refreshing water in the many harbour baths. Photo : Daniel Jensen Winter in Copenhagen isn't just cold; it's an experience . Think twinkling lights, the scent of cinnamon and pine, and a cozy atmosphere that wraps you up like a warm blanket. It's the season of hygge , that uniquely Danish feeling of comfort and contentment. Winter Weather/Temperature: Cold and often snowy, typically between 0-5°C (32-41°F). Layers are your friend – think warm sweaters, waterproof jackets, and definitely a good hat and gloves. Here are some typical things you definitely want to experience in the Copenhagen winter weather: Winter Bathing: A popular activity in Copenhagen, and it's not for the faint of heart. But if you're feeling adventurous, it's an exhilarating way to experience the Danish winter. Take a dip in the icy water, followed by a warming sauna, and you'll feel invigorated and alive. Several harbors and beaches offer winter bathing facilities, often with saunas or hot tubs nearby. It's a truly unique and invigorating experience! Ice Skating: The city boasts several fantastic ice skating rinks. Glide across the ice under the twinkling lights, enjoy some festive music, and embrace the winter spirit. Whether you're a seasoned skater or a beginner, it's a fun activity for all ages. Several rinks pop up throughout the city during the winter months, often with skate rentals available. Cozy Cafés: Copenhagen's café culture is strong year-round, but it really shines in the winter. Find a cozy spot, sink into a comfy armchair, and treat yourself to a rich hot chocolate, a spiced latte, or a flaky pastry. It's the perfect way to warm up after a day of exploring. Winter Walks: Don't let the cold keep you indoors. Copenhagen is beautiful in the winter. Take a stroll through the city's parks, which transform into snowy landscapes. Or explore the charming streets of the old town, where the colorful buildings look even more picturesque dusted with snow. Museum Hopping: If the weather gets too chilly, escape indoors to one of Copenhagen's many world-class museums. From art and design to history and culture, there's something for everyone. And many museums offer special winter exhibitions and events. ➜ Learn more about winter in Copenhagen Spring Weather & Blosomming Vibes Bispebjerg Cemetery On a sunny spring day, Bispebjerg Cemetery makes for a special excursion. Guests come from near and far to take photos of one of the garden’s main attractions: the avenue of Japanese cherry trees that, when in bloom, form a spectacular long, pink tunnel. Photo : Thomas Høyrup Christensen Spring in Copenhagen isn't just a season; it's a transformation . The city shakes off its winter coat, the parks burst into color, and there's a palpable sense of renewal. It's the perfect time to explore, discover, and soak up the vibrant energy. Spring Temperature/Weather in Copenhagen:: Mild and getting warmer, usually between 5-15°C (41-59°F). Layering is key – think light jackets, sweaters, and maybe a scarf for those cooler evenings. Here are some Spring-activities you've got to try: Coastal Exploration: Ditch the city center crowds and head north along the Øresund coast. Charming towns like Elsinore , with its impressive Kronborg Castle (Hamlet's castle!), offer a glimpse into Danish history and stunning sea views. Rent a bike and cycle along the scenic coastal roads, breathing in the fresh sea air. Dyrehaven Delights: Escape to Dyrehaven (Deer Park), a vast, natural park just north of the city. Explore the blooming forests, spot wild deer roaming freely, and enjoy a picnic amidst the greenery. It's a perfect escape from the city bustle. Blossom Bliss: Copenhagen's parks and gardens are at their peak in spring. Wander through the King's Garden , admire the cherry blossoms in Bispebjerg Cemetery , or explore the botanical gardens. It's a feast for the eyes and a perfect spot for a relaxing stroll. Cycling City: Copenhagen is a cycling city year-round, but spring is an especially great time to hop on two wheels. Rent a bike and explore the city at your own pace, discovering hidden gems and enjoying the fresh air. Cycle along the harbor, through the parks, or explore the charming neighborhoods beyond the city center. Harbor Hangouts: As the weather warms up, Copenhagen's harbor comes alive. Grab a coffee or a beer at one of the many waterfront cafes and bars, and watch the boats go by. It's a great place to people-watch and soak up the spring sunshine. Outdoor Dining: Spring is the perfect time to enjoy al fresco dining. Many restaurants and cafes set up outdoor seating areas, allowing you to enjoy your meal while soaking up the spring atmosphere. Spring in Copenhagen is a time of renewal, a chance to experience the city at its most vibrant and beautiful. It's a season for exploring the outdoors, indulging in local flavors, and embracing the energy of a city coming to life. ➜ Read more about spring in Copenhagen Copenhagen Weather During Summer Østergro is a unique urban farm located on a roof top in the heart of the city. Perfect for those vibrant summer evenings. Photo : Daniel Rasmussen Summer in Copenhagen? It's pure hygge under the midnight sun (well, almost!). The city comes alive, buzzing with energy, outdoor events, and a relaxed, carefree vibe. Days are long, and the possibilities are endless. Summer Temperature/Weather: Warm and sunny, typically between 20-25°C (68-77°F). Sunscreen is a must, and light, breezy clothing is your best friend Some of the best activities to enjoy in the Copenhagen summer weather: Harbor Life: Copenhagen's harbor is the heart of the city in summer. Skip the crowded canal tours and explore the waterways by kayak or paddleboard. It's a unique way to see the city from a different perspective. Or simply relax on the harborfront, grab a cold drink, and watch the boats go by. Beach Days: Copenhagen might not be known for its beaches, but the Amager coastline offers some surprisingly good spots for swimming, sunbathing, and watersports. Amager Strandpark is a popular choice, with its sandy beaches, dunes, and clear waters. Park Life: Copenhagen's parks come alive in the summer. Pack a picnic and head to Kongens Have (the King's Garden), Ørstedsparken , or Frederiksberg Have . Enjoy the sunshine, play some frisbee, or simply relax and people-watch. Outdoor Events: Summer is festival season in Copenhagen. From music festivals and food markets to cultural events and open-air concerts, there's always something happening. Street Food Scene: Copenhagen's street food scene is booming, and summer is the perfect time to indulge. Explore the various street food markets and food trucks, offering everything from gourmet burgers and tacos to international delicacies and local specialties. Bike Adventures: Copenhagen is a cycling paradise, and summer is the ideal time to explore the city on two wheels. Rent a bike and cycle along the harbor, through the parks, or explore the charming neighborhoods beyond the city center. Open-Air Bars and Cafés: As the weather warms up, Copenhagen's bars and cafes spill out onto the streets. Enjoy a cold beer, a refreshing cocktail, or a delicious meal at one of the many outdoor seating areas. It's the perfect way to soak up the summer atmosphere and enjoy the long, light evenings. Summer in Copenhagen is all about embracing the outdoor lifestyle, enjoying the long days and warm nights, and soaking up the city's vibrant energy. It's a season for relaxation, exploration, and creating unforgettable memories. ➜ Learn more about summer in Copenhagen Autumn temperature & activities in Copenhagen Royal lifeguards marching by Kings Garden. Photo : Christian Lindgren Autumn in Copenhagen is a study in hygge . The city slows down a bit, the air turns crisp, and the leaves explode into a riot of color. It's a time for cozy sweaters, warm drinks, and appreciating the beauty of nature. Temperature/Weather In Autumn: Cooling down, usually between 10-15°C (50-59°F). Layering is essential – think light jackets, sweaters, and maybe a scarf. Experiences: Forest Hikes: Autumn is the perfect time to explore the forests surrounding Copenhagen. Gribskov , one of Denmark's largest forests, is a must-visit. Hike through the colorful foliage, breathe in the fresh air, and enjoy the tranquility of nature. Nørrebro Exploration: Explore the vibrant and multicultural Nørrebro district. Browse the unique shops and galleries, discover hidden cafes, and soak up the neighborhood's bohemian vibe. It's a great place to experience Copenhagen's diverse cultural scene. Museum Hopping: If the weather turns chilly, escape indoors to one of Copenhagen's many museums. Explore art, design, history, and culture at world-class institutions like the National Museum of Denmark , the Glyptoteket , or the Louisiana Museum of Modern Art (just a short train ride from the city). Harvest Festivals: Autumn is harvest season, and many farms and orchards around Copenhagen host harvest festivals. Pick your own apples, pumpkins, or other seasonal produce, and enjoy the festive atmosphere. Cozy Cafés: Copenhagen's café culture is thriving year-round, but it's especially cozy in the autumn. Find a charming café, curl up with a good book, and enjoy a warm drink like a spiced latte or a rich hot chocolate. Autumn in Tivoli: Tivoli Gardens takes on a special charm in the autumn. The park is decorated with pumpkins, gourds, and other autumnal decorations, creating a cozy and festive atmosphere. Enjoy the rides, explore the gardens, and soak up the autumn ambiance. Art and Design: Autumn is a great time to explore Copenhagen's vibrant art and design scene. Visit galleries, studios, and design shops, and discover the latest trends in Danish creativity. Autumn in Copenhagen is a time for reflection, appreciation of nature's beauty, and embracing the cozy moments that make life special. It's a season for slowing down, enjoying the simple things, and finding hygge in the everyday. ➜ Learn more about autumn in Copenhagen Copenhagen weather/temperature (monthly averages) January: 2.4 (°C) / 36.6 (°F) February: 2.5 (°C) / 36.5 (°F) March: 4.2 (°C) / 39.6(°F) April: 8.0 (°C )/ 46.4 (°F) May: 12.2 (°C )/ 54.0 (°F) June: 16.0 (°C) /61.7 (°F) July: 18.0 (°C) / 64.4 (°F) August: 17.9 (°C) /64.2 (°F) September: 15.0 (°C) /59.0 (°F) October: 10.8 (°C) / 51.4 (°F) November: 7.2 (°C ) / 45.0 (°F) December: 3.7 (°C) / 38.7 (°F) Source: www.dmi.dk Copenhagen sea/water temperature (monthly averages) January: 4-5 (°C) / 39-41 (°F) February: 3-4 (°C) / 37-39 (°F) March: 3-4 (°C) / 37-39 (°F) April: 5-7 (°C) / 41-45 (°F) May: 9-12 (°C) / 48-54 (°F) June: 14-17 (°C) / 57-63 (°F) July: 17-20 (°C) / 63-68 (°F) August: 18-21 (°C) / 64-70 (°F) September: 16-19 (°C) / 61-66 (°F) October: 12-14 (°C) / 54-57 (°F) November: 8-10 (°C) / 46-50 (°F) December: 5-7 (°C) / 41-45 (°F) Source: seatemperature.info Get Social : Useful links Web Accessibility Editorial policy Other sites Wonderful Copenhagen Cruise Denmark – Copenhagen and beyond Copenhagen Convention Bureau Travel Trade Copenhagen Card Intl. press room Contact Contact VisitCopenhagen Visit Copenhagen © 2025 Data Protection Notice English
